newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan PM flies to Peru on thank-you mission.
newsitem.headline: Japan PM flies to Peru on thank-you mission.

text.p: Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto left for Peru on Friday after apologising for Tokyo's handling of the four-month hostage crisis at the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima.
"I am aware of many problematic points. As head of the government, I apologise," Hashimoto told parliament.
"The incident took place where many guests were invited to celebrate the emperor's birthday. As a result of it, three Peruvians died. I am really sorry," he said.
He left on a one-day visit to formally thank Peruvian authorities for their role in the crisis.
Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) rebels took over the Japanese ambassador's home in Lima on December 17 during a lavish reception celebrating the birthday of Emperor Akihito.
The Cuban-inspired rebels took some 500 people hostage and gradually released all but 72.
In a spectacular rescue operation by Peruvian troops on April 22, all but one of the hostages were freed alive. Two soldiers and one hostage died along with all 14 MRTA rebels.
Hashimoto said Japan was partly responsible for lax security which allowed the rebels to storm the building and for the fact that the crisis took so long to end.

"Under the Vienna Convention, Peru as the host country is responsible for security at diplomatic missions," Hashimoto said. "But in the case of the incident this time, there were many problematic points on the part of Japan in obtaining advance information, ensuring security and handling the crisis."
During his rush visit to Lima, Hashimoto will meet Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori and give his condolences to the bereaved families of the three Peruvians.

On Friday, Japan's parliament donated 4.41 million yen ($36,100) -- 10,000 yen each from 441 Lower House lawmakers -- to Peru's embassy in Tokyo with instructions the funds be passed to the bereaved families of the three men and to rescue workers injured in the raid.
